subject: US President Trump says doesn't like EU regulating Google (GOOG)

BoJ minutes from September meeting stated that most members shared the view that the year-on-year rate of change in the CPI was likely to increase gradually toward 2% and that it is appropriate to continue easing persistently
content:
Says:
- Japan's economy is expanding moderately, exports and industrial production on an increasing trend.
- Financial conditions are highly accommodative.
- Most members agreed momentum to target was intact.

Full minutes release: http://www.boj.or.jp/en/mopo/mpmsche_minu/minu_2018/g180919.pdf

subject: Subaru (7270 JT) to delay earnings release by 2 hours to 0600GMT on November 5th
Saudi Arabia is said to be looking at China as a long-term partner to help in the development of the Saudi economy
PREVIEW: BoJ minutes from September 18th-19th meeting due at 2350GMT/1750CST/0750HKT
content:
The BoJ are to release the minutes from the September meeting, where the central bank kept policy unchanged with the bank rate kept at -0.1% and long-term yield target held at around 0.0% as expected. The central bank also left its forward guidance unchanged in which it will keep current extremely low rates for an extended period of time and maintained its pledge to buy JGBs in a flexible manner so holdings rise at an annual pace of about JPY 80tln.

Furthermore, the previously released BoJ Summary of Opinions from the September meeting stated there is room to mull steps to make policy more flexible and that it is necessary to persistently maintain highly accommodative financial conditions while examining positive effects & side effects, while the BoJ also reiterated the need to persistently continue with the current powerful monetary easing as the momentum toward 2 percent inflation is maintained.

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump said on Friday that the US is much closer to doing something on trade with China and that he will make a very good deal with China, while he added he will have dinner with Xi at the G20 summit and that If the US can open up China and make it fair, he is willing to do it. (Newswires)

White House NEC director Kudlow said he wants to keep expectations low on US - China talks and that he doesn't expect detailed trade deal from talks between Trump and Xi. Kudlow also commented that more tariffs on China are possible and Trump has not asked the cabinet to make a China trade plan, while he confirmed he hasn't seen any new proposals from China and is not as optimistic as before that a trade deal will be reached but added If talks improve then tariffs could be removed. (Newswires)

Three senior administration officials told a White House correspondent on Friday that there is no indication of an imminent trade deal with China and that options are always being discussed behind the scenes, but no significant progress. (Twitter)


UK

UK PM May secured private concessions from Brussels that will keep Britain in a customs union and avoid a hard border, while reports also noted Britain is on course for a future economic partnership deal with the EU. (Sunday Times) However, some sources noted that Downing Street had dismissed this as speculation. (Twitter)

UK Brexit Minister Raab said on Friday we have made it "very clear" we won't allow anything that jeopardizes the UK's integrity , while a UK cabinet minister also commented that the British government committed to getting over remaining difficulties ASAP and  there has been positive progress in the last few weeks. (Newswires)

Ireland PM Varadkar said Brexit has undermined ‘Good Friday Agreement’ and is wearing on ties between Britain and Ireland, while he added we need guarantees that there will be no hard border in Ireland no matter what outcome. (Newswires)

Irish Foreign Minister Coveney said on Friday it is possible to get a deal in November as they are very close, but not quite there yet, while Coveney added they have made a lot of progress in the recent weeks and EU’s Barnier has shown flexibility. (Newswires)


EU

ECB's Rehn (Non-Voter, Dovish) said 1.6%-1.8% inflation is "to my mind" not yet below but close to 2% and suggested that a more symmetric assessment should be adopted. (Newswires)

Sources said no decision will be made on the ECB TLTRO at the December policy meeting and one source said the TLTRO would help banks to avoid a 'cliff edge' in 2020. Furthermore, another source said TLTRO only needed if policy transmission mechanism was hampered. (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

Baker Hughes Rig Count (02/Nov): Oil rigs down 1 at 874, gas rigs unchanged at 193, total rigs down 1 at 1067. (Newswires)

US President Trump confirmed that sanctions on Iran including energy, shipping and banking will take effect on November 5th. In related news, Iraqi officials said the US is to grant Baghdad a waiver over some Iran sanctions. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

North Korea reportedly warned to resume its nuclear program if US sanctions continue, according to reports which cited the Foreign Ministry’s Institute for American Studies Director Kwon Jong Gun. (KCNA)
 

US

US Non-Farm Payrolls Oct 250k vs. Exp. 190.0k (Prev. 134.0k, Rev. 118k); two-month net revisions 0k (Prev. 87k). (Newswires)
US Average Earnings YY Oct 3.1% vs. Exp. 3.1% (Prev. 2.8%)
US Unemployment Rate Oct 3.7% vs. Exp. 3.7% (Prev. 3.7%)
 

MARKET RECAP

 

Some heavyweight earnings from stocks including Apple (AAPL) which tumbled, losing its USD 1trln status, after it lowered expectations for sales in the next quarter. Other earnings reports came from energy names Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX) which both beat EPS estimates pushing them higher, Starbucks (SBUX) surged following strong sales in the US and China, and Kraft Heinz (KHZ) failed as a condiment to these gains after it traded lower on missing its EPS estimates. VeriSign (VRSN) was a top mover following regulatory approval for it to increase its prices. Synchrony Financial (SYF) took a dive after Walmart (WMT) announced it is suing it for breaching terms of their contract. SPX -0.65% at 2723, NDX -1.47% at 6965, DJI -0.44% at 25268.
